R: @robertwb
Could you make the identifiers actual names (e.g. `_CompressionType('zlib')`) while you're at it. (Actually, I think it'd be good to clean up this and use an actual Python enum class.)
BTW, not having write privileges to the project, I can't actually close this issue not that it's merged and resolved, so could you?

Also, could you merge and let me know if I can close?
Yes, enums can wait 'till a followup. I'll merge as soon as I verify tests pass.
Ha. I was wondering what you hadn't closed it. Okay, doing so. Thanks for the merge!

We've chatted, and my desire that "you should be able to run the local tests" is satisfied. We uncovered some issues, which is expected since the tests haven't been running. We can resolve them asynchronously, via other PRs and/or longer term tickets.

LGTM
Minor comments and then LGTM
LGTM

Okay, got all PipelineOptionsFactoryTests to pass.  Now I'm looking into why https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-beam/jobs/162031186 is failing, with missing getters (e.g. Expected getter for property [foo] of type [java.lang.String]) from ProxyInvocationHandlerTest.

With respect to the List<Integer> vs. List<Long>, it looks like that fails at compile time because the post-erasure types are equivalent (if that's what you were going for.)
As far as I can tell, those Travis failures are unrelated to this PR. Not sure why they're happening, though.
Thanks for merging in Robert. Closing...

Seems like there are some test failures.

Updated with `RowMapper` and `ElementInserter`. The `Write` doesn't use `autocommit` anymore and commit per bundle.
I wonder if it would not make sense to provide a default `RowMapper` populated the `PCollection` with `String` (as CSV format). WDYT ?
I did a mistake on the commit I wanted to push. I'm fixing the issues. Sorry about that.
I'm fixing Javadoc issue.

R: @robertwb
Implementation of Avro sinks without Coders. R: @chamikaramj
Added batching for Write, use of a preparedStatementSetter with query for write.

Agree with your comments. My concern is about data source. Even if the interface is not serializable most of implementations are. I think it's better to let user define his own data source in order to deal with connection pooling, etc. Thoughts ?

It might be the case that most DataSource are serializable; but the user will be unable to use this connector with those that aren't; and there's no fundamental reason why this has to be the case.
With the proposed ConnectionFactory interface, the user can still use a DataSource under the hood. For cases when the DataSource is in fact serializable, you could even supply a convenience method "withDataSource(DataSource, username, password)" that would delegate to withConnectionFactory, supplying a ConnectionFactory that creates the connection using this Datasource, username and password. But this way the user also has an escape hatch when the DataSource is not serializable but there still is some way to create a connection.
Let me think and experiment this. I don't think ConnectionFactory is a good name as it's confusing with JMS ConnectionFactory. Thanks. I'm preparing updates.
Thanks for the PR @kennknowles. Processing time support definitely needs to be fixed. The changes look sensible to me but I would wait for @aljoscha opinion on this.

Implemented large part of the comments. TODO:
1. use custom serializable interface instead of directly `DataSource`. I'm thinking about implementing all that I need to actually create the datasource (datasource class name, jdbc URL, ...)
2. re-use of the same connection object between `Read` and `Write` to avoid code duplication
3. better handling of exception in `WriteFn` (to remove the element from the batch list only if the corresponding statement has been executed successfully).
I'm evaluating using of DBCP2 and let user provide driver classname, JDBC URL, and optionally username, password, and pooling size.

This would work but not in the presence of failures/recovery because timers need to be checkpointed, as we do with the event-time timers in `WindowDoFnOperator`.

I'm currently working on an addition to Flink that would provide user code with an interface that allows setting processing-time/event-time timers that would also be kept in a fault-tolerant way by the system. Maybe we should wait for that and then update `WindowDoFnOperator` to use that for both event-time timers and processing-time timers.
R: @chamikaramj
R: @jbonofre
By the way, your PR contains javadoc errors. Please fix it. Thanks.

I see. I first considered duplicating the logic for event-time timers, but I had hoped the shortcut of using the underlying Flink timers would work. I will close this PR, leaving the open question of whether to emulate the event-time timer logic vs wait for the fault-tolerant Flink APIs.
R: @charlesccychen

> With respect to the List vs. List, it looks like that fails at compile time because the post-erasure types are equivalent (if that's what you were going for.)

Not sure I understand this. Does:

`options.as(SomeClassWithListInteger.class).as(SomeClassWithListLong.class);`

fail at compile time? That would surprise me but I may be missing something subtle.

If it passes at compile time, I'd hope we could determine at runtime that this was doomed.
R: @chamikaramj
By the way, the build fails due a test failure in the Spark runner (RecoverFromCheckpointStreamingTest). I'm checking on master and fixing.
R: @robertwb
Travis has an unrelated timeout + a green run: https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-beam/builds/162847913

Wouldn't this unconditional clear it? If we want a fresh directory, we should use tempfiles mechanisms to give us a fresh one each time (and attempt to delete it after use). More importantly, if this is used as a cache, it should be safe to re-use or there's a bug here, right?

> Wouldn't this unconditional clear it?

Yes

>  If we want a fresh directory, we should use tempfiles mechanisms to give us a fresh one each time (and attempt to delete it after use).

There is a separate test which tests overriding the cache directory, [`test_with_requirements_file_and_cache`](https://github.com/swegner/incubator-beam/blob/9ec4c926f0038f974e79afe0e65e200ef2a23c3e/sdks/python/apache_beam/utils/dependency_test.py#L152). So, the value of [`test_with_requirements_file`](https://github.com/swegner/incubator-beam/blob/9ec4c926f0038f974e79afe0e65e200ef2a23c3e/sdks/python/apache_beam/utils/dependency_test.py#L113) is only that it validates the behavior when the default cache location is used. Seems only marginally valuable to me, so I'd be fine dropping the test.

> More importantly, if this is used as a cache, it should be safe to re-use or there's a bug here, right?

This may point to an issue in [`dependency.stage_job_resources`](https://github.com/swegner/incubator-beam/blob/9ec4c926f0038f974e79afe0e65e200ef2a23c3e/sdks/python/apache_beam/utils/dependency.py#L208). It internally calls [`populate_requirements_cache`](https://github.com/swegner/incubator-beam/blob/9ec4c926f0038f974e79afe0e65e200ef2a23c3e/sdks/python/apache_beam/utils/dependency.py#L194) which is strictly additive-- it uses `pip` to download requested dependencies into the cache, but doesn't clear non-requested ones. It then gathers a list of all resources using [a file glob of the cache directory](https://github.com/swegner/incubator-beam/blob/9ec4c926f0038f974e79afe0e65e200ef2a23c3e/sdks/python/apache_beam/utils/dependency.py#L270). As a result, the final list of resources may contain previously cached resources.

It seems we are using the cache directory as a sandbox area to resolve transitive dependencies needed to stage. But since it's reused, we are getting extra files.
I always stick my virtualenv outside the repository, but I think it's worth having this as well.
LGTM
If this goes through I'll start working on splittable bz2
Implemented second round. I'm now working on last comment of the first round (removing `DataSource`).

tests passed
PTAL

I'm not sure why Travis has stalled. For the record travis said it was fine on [my forked branch](https://travis-ci.org/tim1357/incubator-beam/builds/162886767). Is there a way to get it to try to build it again?

Edit: I figured it out.
I've opened [BEAM-680](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-680) to track the issue with staging extra cached dependencies.

- it runs unconditionally rather than behind a profile
- it seems to find a different list of failures than the normal Javadoc build does.

Let me take a look.

I think this PR could be extended with not much work to checkpoint processing time timers in the `snapshotOperatorState(..)` method. It might be worth doing that because the next Flink release will only be available in a couple of months.
Does the second commit make sense to you now?
The code LGTM but I would like to have all checks OK. So, let me fix the build on master, then I will let you know to rebase and the PR should be OK.

In IntelliJ, you can run "all in directory" for the core SDK, but with the classpath of the module `beam-runners-direct-java` to run them all with the direct runner. @tgroh, do you recommend this or another way? 

Does the issue repro in the direct runner?

Hey JB, I'd like to make sure the owners of the Python SDK/runner are the ones to review this code, and then maybe they can ask you to merge (if @robertwb is not available).

R: @charlesccychen @chamikaramj @mariapython

@mbuccini Thank you for doing this.

I have a concern about making `cython` an optional dependency.

If a user has `cython` already installed and they installed the beam package as `pip install -e .` this will not check for the required version of `cython` but still use it. Since the setup code will try to import it.

Could we check the version requirement similar to the one check you do for `pip`? If `cython` is importable use `pkg_resources` to get the version and compare against our requirement.

Code LGTM.

Jenkins seems stuck. Have you run anything with the Dataflow runner with this change?
R: @jbonofre
I ran the BigtableWriteIT and it passed after getting the appropriate permissions.
This PR has been subsumed by later changes, and can be closed.

I worry about this. The fact that this is necessary means that there are cases where the ClassLoader that pulled in DoFnInvokers differs from the ClassLoader of the thread running user code. Is this only happening in specific runners? It would be good to understand the cases this can happen.

The larger potential problem is that we cache the loaded class. So, with just this change, we're now assuming that whichever ClassLoader was associated with the thread the first time we created a DoFnInvoker will always be the ClassLoader associated with all future threads that create DoFnInvokers.

Given that the first assumption (they're the same) is being violated, how do we know the second is a valid assumption? If we need to go down this route (and we should understand the runner environment leading to it), we may need to have a per-ClassLoader cache of the DoFnInvoker classes, allowing us to load it into each ClassLoader we need it in.

@kennknowles That's the way I do it, and I don't believe that there's another way - the classpath modification is roughly equivalent to the maven test suppressions and classpath-scanning that we perform.
PTAL

@bjchambers We noticed this in FlinkRunner.  The class which generated NoClassDefError is available in user classloader.

Attached is the stack trace that i got.
